results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 35]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows various scenes of life in the Anderson family, including the kids riding a dirt bike, holidays at the beach, and birthday parties.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 family and friends arriving to the house with presents
00:02:03:00 all the kids taking turns on the new Honda dirt bike
00:05:42:00 relaxing at the beach
00:06:12:00 on the dirt bike track
00:08:30:00 riding the dirt bike on the beach
00:10:38:00 couple lounging on the beach
00:11:15:00 teenage girls laughing at the camera
00:12:55:00 boy carrying four ice cream cones dripping on him
00:13:29:00 cricket in the front yard
00:14:01:00 Marie and friends on the beach in stylish sunglasses and bikinis
00:14:24:00 boogie boarding
00:16:49:00 cooking sausages on an open BBQ
00:17:00:00 horse riding on a bush trail
00:19:15:00 kids’ birthday party
00:20:02:00 birthday cake with ‘Happy Birthday Paul’ on top
00:20:08:00 kids’ bike gang
00:20:38:00 musical chairs
00:21:42:00 boy animatedly blowing out candles
00:23:19:00 kids taking turns on the trampoline
00:26:31:00 slow motion trampoline jumping

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 34]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film begins with scenes of kids’ birthday parties, horse riding and sports in Ballarat. The family then make a road trip to South Australia, featuring city streets in Adelaide, a visit to an amusement park and a wildlife sanctuary, and more horse riding.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 kids’ athletics day
00:01:16:00 girl dismounting a horse from the back of the saddle
00:02:05:00 horse-riding at an equestrian club
00:07:13:00 a group of kids having fun on a trampoline
00:07:30:00 riding a horse in the backyard
00:08:05:00 kids seated around a table eating cake
00:08:50:00 blowing out the candles on the cake
00:10:24:00 playing musical chairs
00:12:01:00 kids’ footy (AFL football) match
00:14:01:00 a nun cheering from the sidelines
00:16:05:00 parents watching from the sidelines
00:18:31:00 man riding a horse down a suburban street
00:20:45:00 on a road trip, at the border of South Australia
00:21:59:00 fish and chips on the bonnet of the car
00:23:25:00 busy Adelaide street with Colonial Mutual Life Assurance Society building in the background
00:24:09:00 in a department store
00:24:53:00 the kids on a Ferris Wheel and other carnival rides
00:25:50:00 trained seals doing tricks
00:28:00:00 dolphins jumping through rings
00:29:42:00 group family shot at a wildlife sanctuary
00:30:56:00 kids patting a kangaroo
00:32:00:00 kids walking down the steps of an ANSETT plane
00:33:12:00 one of the kids on a tire swing
00:34:18:00 cowboy on a horse
00:34:52:00 paddling around in kayaks on a lake
00:36:23:00 on a boat cruising down the river
00:37:08:00 old steam trains in a yard
00:37:15:00 city streets including trams
00:37:58:00 boys running down train tracks
00:39:01:00 arriving home and pulling suitcases out of the boot of the car

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 26]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows a family holiday to sunny Surfers Paradise, Queensland. The family visit the theme parks Ski Land and Marineland, which combined to become Sea World in 1972. The film features some great holiday footage of the motel pool, theme parks and the beach at Surfers Paradise, along with notable 70s fashion.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:07:00 motel sign ‘Surfside 6: Holiday – Overnight’
00:00:19:00 kids playing in the motel pool
00:03:07:00 enjoying milkshakes and icy-poles
00:03:27:00 on a chairlift
00:04:35:00 water skiiers doing tricks at Ski Land
00:07:06:00 a pyramid of people on water skis carrying flags reading ‘Ski Land’
00:08:28:00 dolphins performing tricks in a pool at Marineland
00:09:33:00 a trainer and a girl in a bikini holding out a fish on a platform over the pool for a dolphin who leaps into the air; the trainer pushes the girl into the water
00:11:10:00 riding on three-person bikes called ‘Silly Cycles’
00:12:26:00 The Sands Hotel
00:13:53:00 rainbow lorikeets
00:14:30:00 riding on a toy train around the park grounds
00:15:00:00 boarding an ANSETT plane

results.title: Pandemonium
results.creator_credit: Haydn Keenan, Tra La La Films, Smart Street Films and KFM Pandemonium
results.brief_description: Haydn Keenan’s “Pandemonium” is a schlock horror movie that aims to displease by entertaining themes of Neo-Nazism, torture, vampirism, incest, sado-masochism, mental illness, necrophilia and bestiality. In the opening sequence Kales Leadingham has escaped from a lunatic asylum. Arriving at a bus stop be relays his travails (in flashback) to a woman seated there. One day at Bondi Beach, Sydney, a woman ‘Dingo Girl’ arrives in search of answers to her past (cue unremitting shots of Dingo Girl’s large breasts, a la Russ Meyer). Shortly after Dingo Girl and Kale enter a warehouse where a bizarre array of subversive types reside. Inhabitants engage in ritualistic Neo-Nazi ceremonies that result in sado-masochistic sex. Amid other activities, a foetus is placed in a blender, Little Adolph has his penis cut off, cloning experiments go awry - whilst numerous musical interludes interrupt the action. Deliberately provocative, and seeking to shock, this film revels in its low-budget amateurism and artlessness. Aesthetically it shares much in common with “Flesh for Frankenstein” and “Rocky Horror Picture Show” but has no hope of achieving the cult status of these enduring films, principally because its relentlessly over-the-top mood and delivery rob it of any impact as comedy or as horror. The unremitting black humour, shoddy sets, trashy costuming, bad taste themes and poor acting, make “Pandemonium” a curio of Australian filmmaking. Cast includes David Argue, Amanda Dole, Esben Storm, Ian Nimmo, Gary Foley, Haydn Keenan, Ignatius Jones, Lex Marinos.

description_for_label: Haydn Keenan’s “Pandemonium” is a schlock horror movie that aims to displease by entertaining themes of Neo-Nazism, torture, vampirism, incest, sado-masochism, mental illness, necrophilia and bestiality. In the opening sequence Kales Leadingham has escaped from a lunatic asylum. Arriving at a bus stop be relays his travails (in flashback) to a woman seated there. One day at Bondi Beach, Sydney, a woman ‘Dingo Girl’ arrives in search of answers to her past (cue unremitting shots of Dingo Girl’s large breasts, a la Russ Meyer). Shortly after Dingo Girl and Kale enter a warehouse where a bizarre array of subversive types reside. Inhabitants engage in ritualistic Neo-Nazi ceremonies that result in sado-masochistic sex. Amid other activities, a foetus is placed in a blender, Little Adolph has his penis cut off, cloning experiments go awry - whilst numerous musical interludes interrupt the action. Deliberately provocative, and seeking to shock, this film revels in its low-budget amateurism and artlessness. Aesthetically it shares much in common with “Flesh for Frankenstein” and “Rocky Horror Picture Show” but has no hope of achieving the cult status of these enduring films, principally because its relentlessly over-the-top mood and delivery rob it of any impact as comedy or as horror. The unremitting black humour, shoddy sets, trashy costuming, bad taste themes and poor acting, make “Pandemonium” a curio of Australian filmmaking. Cast includes David Argue, Amanda Dole, Esben Storm, Ian Nimmo, Gary Foley, Haydn Keenan, Ignatius Jones, Lex Marinos.

results.title: Living with happiness
results.creator_credit: Sarah Watt and Sarah Watt Productions
results.brief_description: A young mother finds herself gripped by an overwhelming pessimism that threatens to consume her. Only a freak accident on a lonely beach may be the key to her future happiness. Voices performed by Sigrid Thornton and William McInnes. (Awards: Winner, Emirates AFI Award for Best Animation, 2001)

results.title: Sidney Nolan
results.brief_description: Sidney Nolan’s interest in and pre-occupation with Australian history and legend have earned him the affectionate title “The Songman of his tribe”. Nolan’s imaginative and poetic vision is revealed in some 150 paintings. His earliest works and his series on Ned Kelly, Mrs Frazer, Bourke and Wills, the Australian outback, Eureka Stockade, Leda and the swan, and Gallipoli, give a rare insight into the mind and stature of this artist. Also shows the artist at work in his studio.

results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a schoolboy game of cricket being played on the turf wicket in the grounds of the Glamorgan Preparatory School in Toorak, Victoria. Glamorgan is the Toorak campus of the Geelong Grammar School in Geelong Victoria. The boys wear Geelong Grammar school caps. Behind the cricket pitch we can see the rooftops and chimneys of the grand homes of Toorak. There is a colourfully painted wall behind the cricketers depicting a scene of Governor Phillip raising the flag at Sydney Cove in 1788. A hand painted didactic says:
“Governor Phillip brought the First Fleet to anchor at Botany Bay but raised the flag at Sydney Cove January 26th 1788. This was the first Australia Day.”

We see the Glamorgan Vs Visitors scoreboard, runs being made, catches being taken and 4s being scored.

The film then takes us to a suburban backyard to show a young baby on a rug. There is some lovely footage of the baby trying to crawl, wearing a handmade necklace made from wooden cotton reels. The baby shares the backyard with other children who play on climbing equipment and engage with the baby.

We see a toddler dressed in rompers standing inside a playpen. The toddler pushes the playpen along from the inside, walking out onto a verandah. There is some delightful footage of a baby crawling along a garden path and playing in a container of water.

The film shows children playing and swimming in an above ground backyard swimming pool. They have kickboards and rubber rings which could be bicycle tyres. They take turns somersaulting into the water from the edge of the pool. After finishing swimming, and wrapped in towels, the children eat drum-stick style ice creams.

This film shows good examples of family at-home recreation and play equipment, including climbing equipment and a swimming pool. There are also examples of suburban architecture, children’s and babies’ fashion, baby paraphernalia such as a playpen, school sports playing fields and turf cricket.

This film was originally made on 16mm.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:25:00 School cricket match with painted Australia Day/Governor Phillip scene behind
00:03:52:00 Glamorgan score board
00:05:21:00 School boys playing cricket, umpire (teacher) and painted wall behind
00:06:50:00 Baby with necklace of wooden cotton reels
00:09:08:00 Toddler inside playpen, walking out onto the verandah
00:09:28:00 Toddler crawls across the verandah
00:10:51:00 Toddler in rompers crawling along a garden path to play in container of water
00:14:01:00 Children playing in backyard pool

results.title: Spread your wings: making it with TAFE
results.creator_credit: John O'Shea, Chris Stewart, Technical and Further Education and Documentary Films
results.brief_description: An impressionistic film which is intended to provide information about the opportunities offered by Technical and Further Education in vocational training, and in recreational courses to meet community requirements. It is not intended to give detailed information on the breadth of courses and curricula but is rather a stimulus film aimed at encouraging enrolment.

results.title: Holiday album
results.creator_credit: Roy A. Driver and Herschells Films
results.brief_description: Snapshots from a family holiday album show tourist attractions throughout Victoria: recreation in the metropolitan area; winter sports at Mt Buffalo; springtime in the Grampians; a leisurely journey down the Murray in the paddle-steamer “Coonawarra”; sailing and fishing at Lakes Entrance; forest country at Marysville; the beaches along the Great Ocean Road. Commentary by Robert Peach.
